newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU divisions on Iraq cast shadow over meeting.
newsitem.headline: EU divisions on Iraq cast shadow over meeting.

text.p: Divisions among European Union countries over Washington's actions in Iraq are expected to overshadow a weekend meeting of EU foreign ministers in Ireland, called in part to find common ground on matters of diplomacy.
The meeting -- on Saturday and Sunday in Tralee, County Kerry -- is also expected to discuss Bosnia, the flagging Middle East peace process and trade relations with the United States.

There are no formal plans to discuss Iraq at the long-scheduled meeting. But EU officials said the U.S. missile attacks this week and Europe's failure to agree a joint position on them had thrust the issue on to the agenda.

EU heavyweights Britain and Germany have strongly supported America's cruise missile strikes on targets in Iraq to punish the government of Saddam Hussein for attacks into the so-called Kurdish safe havens in the north.
But France, Spain and Italy have studiously withheld endorsement.
Senior EU diplomats failed on Tuesday to agree a joint position for the 15-nation bloc, leaving the matter to the ministers at the weekend.
The Tralee meeting is a twice-yearly informal gathering without a formal agenda at which theoretically no decisions can be taken.
But these informal meetings are often used as a way of setting EU policy.
Irish Foreign Minister Dick Spring, host in Tralee, has told his colleagues he wants to discuss what response the EU should have to the September 14 elections in Bosnia.
"Everybody knows they won't be fair and free but they will be moderately democratic," said one diplomat, adding that the main task afterwards would be to build up Bosnian institutions.
Carl Bildt, the international community's Bosnia moderator, will brief ministers on Saturday. Policy on other parts of the former Yugoslavia will also be discussed.

Spring has also asked his colleagues to consider the EU's role in the Middle East peace process. "We will need to consider, in particular, how we can best encourage Israel to re-engage in the peace process," he wrote.
Diplomats said there was some frustration in the bloc over the policies of the new Israeli government. Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy was to meet Spring in Dublin on Thursday.
The ministers will also consider what steps, if any, the EU needs to take to respond to U.S. trade laws designed to punish Cuba, Iran and Libya.

The laws, known as the Helms-Burton and D'Amato acts, have infuriated the EU and America's trading partners because of provisions threatening sanctions on non-U.S. companies doing certain types of business with the three companies.
Retaliation measures, drafted by the European Commission at the ministers request, will be presented at the meeting, diplomats said.
In internal EU matters, the ministers will discuss the status of the inter-governmental conference (IGC), the bloc's review of its treaties.

Spring is expected to push for a date to be set for a special EU summit, due in October. Although EU leaders asked for the meeting, they have been unable to agree on a date, providing EU presidency Ireland with a logistical headache.
